column4: if I move a bunch of files across to a Windows partition from Linux, will that info still be on the Linux partition?
what are the options?
if you mount the partition, you will see the files on yoru windows partiton
often you have to mount the NTFS partiton,, look into NTFS-3g
yes, you can do that and run prorams from it if you choose.. BUT be careful of permissions and what not
my question is if the info on the harddrive will still be recoverable on the windows partition
yer of course, windows will see it without issue..
i run steam that way.. so linux or windows can use it.. saves on install space :)
I'm confused.  My linux can see windows files fine.  I'm asking ...like, you know how when you delete something, it doesn't delete the data, just the pointer?
if you delete something from your windows partition, while in linux.. it will be deleted. when you boot to windows, it will be gone
pretend I have one OS.  Just Windows.  Or Linux.  Doesn't matter.  If you have a file, and delete it, that information is stil on the disk until something writes it over.
correct.
BUT the pointer file (FAT info) ISNT moved to the recycle bin for easy access.. you manually have to run some sort of undelete / unerase program to rebuild it
okay, so when I move a file from a linux partition to a windows partition, I'd have to wipe it from the linux partition if I don't want it to be there anymore
I don't think it's bios if he can't use the CD at all
umm. if you MOVE it, it tells the FAT (file allocation table) taht the space can now be overwritten.. you dont have to actively "scrub" it. if you move it, your all set
OH... is the CD burnt in a bootable way ? i had to deal with someone about this issue previously
I don't have to scrub it, but I want to.
ok.. there is a "secure erase" option.. so it writes all blank space (FFFFFFxFF) over it... a move is "copy, delete".. a secure move / secure delete is "delete, write over it with blank space"..
if you do it via nautilus, if you "empty" your recycle bin, sorta does the same thing
yup, wipe is good
so I think I should just copy all the files to the Windows partition, and then wipe all them from the Ubuntu partition
